;One of the pleasures of Middle East living employed to be buying for old jewelry-specially old Bedouin jewelry, rich in intricate silverwork, coral, carnelian and rather stones picked up from the hills and sands throughout the Bedouin's movements.
;
;Currently, the handmade jewellery that as soon as graced the persons of desert nomads is disappearing. The Bedouins themselves are exchanging it for modern-day pieces jewellery. The jewellers in the cities are breaking the jewels and remodeling it for present day pieces. Artisans who the moment made the jewelry are retiring or altering the way they function. And most of what remains is already in private collections and museums.
;
;According to experts, this trend is widespread. In Saudi Arabia silversmiths are melting down Bedouin jewelry and recasting the silver in new models. In Karak, in Jordan, two Yemeni jewelers who set the styles in jewellery for numerous generations have retired. In Beirut a jeweler who could once confirm the stamp of a particular craftsman or pick out a method characteristic to him says that the old work doesn't pay any longer.
;
;Why? Since lifestyle and values are changing drastically as the Bedouins settle down. The Bedouins are not at all reluctant to alter the rigors of life in the desert for the comforts, and the opportunities of existence in towns or villages. And wives are no less reluctant to exchange pieces engraved by hand in patterns as old as tribal tradition, for costume jewelry fresh from a factory stamping machine.
;
;Most Bedouin styles probably go back to ancient southern Iraq, popular in Biblical times for gold and silver mined from the Kurdistan hills. One more influence was Rome. Funeral busts in Palmyra, Syria, from the initially-century A.D. show similarities to what was worn in the days of Caesars and what is worn by Bedouins currently.
